Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Improving the Quality and Reducing the Burden of Producing and Reusing Publicly Accessible Research Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Reusability of research data is central to successfully maximizing the benefits of public access to publicly funded research outputs. The purpose of this EAGER proposal is to improve understanding of factors that lead to reusability of research data. It proposes to do this by 1) developing a framework for understanding data reusability, 2) identify concomitant practices for improving data reusability, and 3) propose a path for accelerating the data reusability readiness of the research community. The project would accomplish this through targeted research and feedback sought through a group meeting. <br/><br/>Research teams at Iowa State University and the University of Virginia will pursue this goal by first gathering descriptive information on targeted research communities with different levels of maturity in their practices of research data sharing and reuse, as well as trusted repositories that have adopted practices for evaluating data sources prior to data ingest and reuse. This descriptive information will inform a draft framework articulating common elements of data reuse, and processes for depositing data in ways that promote reusability. The framework will also examine incentives and barriers to data reusability. Feedback from a community meeting will inform subsequent refinement of the framework, which will be used in small scale tests using publicly accessible data sets and research groups at ISU and UVA. The final version of the framework would include a discussion of strategies for accelerating the sharing of research data and the corresponding culture changes needed for success.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fostering Impact and Ease in Producing and Reusing Publicly Accessible Research Data 

SM Nusser (Iowa State University), AM Mikytuck (Randolph-Macon College), G Korkmaz (Westat)

Our project sought to improve the reusability and impact of publicly accessible research data by 1) identifying context needed by researchers who use publicly accessible research data (data users) to be successful in understanding, evaluating and appropriately analyzing shared data sources; 2) outlining practices that help those who generate shared data (data producers) improve the quality of their data, reduce their effort in preparing data, and minimize reputational risks; and 3) developing a field-independent model of research practices in the data sharing and reuse cycle that fosters the success of all researchers.

Data users leverage an unexpectedly wide range of resources in assessing and using shared data. In addition to the widely cited need for metadata describing a data source’s contents, users rely on detailed information on study design, data generation methods, and code used to process and analyze the data source. They use this information to evaluate the credibility of the data source and to understand, evaluate and properly analyze the data source. Descriptions of data provenance and terms of use are key to outlining appropriate uses for the data source and any obligations that data user has in stewarding the shared data. Globally unique and persistent identifiers for the researcher, their institution and funders are used to assess the reputation of data producers and repositories where data are made public accessible. 

Data producers generally have limited understanding of context needed by data users and may not know how to reduce burden and minimize risks in preparing and quality data sources. Our work highlights the need to dedicate far more effort in planning for data sharing before the study begins to both reduce producer burden and foster data reusability. Planning for data sharing (as opposed to study design) involves specifying what digital objects will be shared with the data (e.g., study design, software code, data use agreement), how that information will be generated and updated throughout the research project, and how research outputs will be packaged and shared for reuse. Detailed planning not only enhances quality of the data and documentation, it provides the foundation for another key strategy – standardizing protocols and formats where possible and automating research processes to reduce burden and improve consistency throughout the research pipeline. Establishing workflows and tools for automation and standardization enables a third strategy: the internal sharing of digital objects among research team members during the research project, which serves as preparation and testing for ultimately releasing a snapshot of the data and its documentation for future users.

Data users can also increase the effectiveness of their practice by focusing on the planning phase. In particular, they should explicitly identify and seek context needed to support their assessment of the relevance of the data source for their research objectives, the data source’s quality and potential flaws, and how they can appropriately steward and analyze the data to protect the integrity of the data source and its producer. Extra attention to terms of use is needed for data that require protection due to confidentiality, proprietary or national security concerns. In addition, users can promote success for themselves and producers by citing the data source and its producers in scholarly outputs. 

These results emphasize the need to cultivate positive interdependence between data producers and data users, a relationship where the behaviors of each party foster the success of the other party. As a guide, we developed a model that summarizes connection points between producers and users in the data sharing and reuse cycle that are key to enhancing each party’s success. The strategies cited above for reducing burden and increasing effectiveness are meant to foster this success and minimize the likelihood of individualistic actions that promote negative interdependence. For example, if a producer develops the type of documentation needed by future users to properly use shared data and provide credit to the producer, then their downstream impact is improved as other researchers extend their findings and increase the producer’s visibility through citations. The producer can reap strong benefits from their efforts to provide quality documentation and digital objects by implementing methods to capture documentation and check data during the research process (e.g., creating standards, protocols and algorithms to share and update this information internally with their research group before posting it publicly). This reduces total effort in generating data and documentation and increases the quality of shared research outputs. Similarly, users can uphold their end of the relationship not only by citing the data and giving credit to the producers, but also by taking the time to fully understand appropriate uses of the data source and proactively identifying resources to meet computational and security requirements associated with the data.
